document.title: The Exponential Decay of Gluing Maps and Gromov-Witten Invariants
document.toctitle: The Exponential Decay of Gluing Maps and Gromov-Witten Invariants

creator.contact: Department of Mathematics, Sichuan University Chengdu, PRC

abstract.name: Abstract.
abstract.p: We prove the exponential decay of the derivative of the gluing maps with respect to the gluing parameter, therefore the Gromov-Witten invariants can be defined as an integral over top strata of virtual neighborhood.

document.acknowledgements: partially supported by a NSFC grant

para.p: In the early 90’s, Ruan [R1] introduced a new invariant to the symplectic manifold by counting J-holomorphic maps from a Riemann surface to a fixed symplectic manifold. Ruan called his invariant Donaldson type invariant because he was modeling his invariant on Donaldson invariants. Ruan’s invariant immediately captured attention from a large community of mathematician and was renamed as Gromov-Ruan invariant [F-1],[F-2] or Gromov-Ruan-Witten invariant [ST]. In the subsequent year the invariant became commonly known as Gromov-Witten invariant. Let (M,ω) be a compact symplectic manifold. We choose a ω-tame almost complex structure :J→⁢TM⁢TM and fix a homology class ∈A⁢H2(M,Z) Let ⁢¯MA(M,g,m) be the compactified moduli space of stable J- holomorphic maps into M of homology class A from Riemann surfaces of genus g with m marked points. One can define a topology on ⁢¯MA(M,g,m). It is well-known that ⁢¯MA(M,g,m) is a compact Hausdorff space.

Ruan’s original definition is a geometric counting of J-holomorphic maps weighted by the order of their automorphisms. It has the advantage of being rational numbers. However, his construction only works for so-called semi-positive symplectic manifold. In the effort to remove semi-positive condition, the technology went on a significant change. For example, the latter approach focuses on the existence of the fundamental class. There had been several different approaches to define Gromov-Witten Invariants for general symplectic manifolds, such as Fukaya-Ono [FO], Li-Tian [LT], Liu-Tian [LiuT], Ruan [R2], Siebert [S] and etc. Since then, almost twenty year has passed. Recently, there is a great deal of interest among symplectic geometric community to re-visit the latter approach with the purpose to clean up some of issues. This is where we feel that this article can make some contributions.

Let’s describe our technique. Classically, one way to treat fundamental class of an oriented differential manifold is to use differential form and its integration. The moduli space is not smooth. However, it can be embedded at least locally into a smooth manifold called virtual neighborhood. Therefore, the differential form technique can still be applied. The main complication is that the moduli space has various lower strata. How to deal with these lower strata is one of main issues discussed recently. Our main idea is that if we can show that the relevant differential form decays in certain rate near lower strata, the Gromov-Witten invariants can be defined as an integral over top strata of virtual neighborhood. Therefore, all the complication near lower strata of the moduli space can be avoided entirely. This technique was first invented by Li-Ruan in the relative theory setting. In [LR] the estimates is of order r-2 where →r∞ is certain gluing parameter. In this paper we improve it to the order of exponential decay exp(-⁢cr). When the transversality fails we need to take the stabilization ( we use the terminology ”regularization” in this paper). By a standard regularization procedure (see [R3, CT, CLW, LR]) we get a finite dimensional virtual orbifold system

Math.text: conditional-set@(vector@(U _ I, E _ I, sigma _ I), I subset-of set@(1, 2, cdots, n))

para.p: indexed by a partially ordered set (=I2{1,2,⋯,n},⊂). Let =Λ{ΛI} be a partition of unity and {ΘI} be a virtual Euler form of {EI} such that ⁢ΛIΘI is compactly supported in UI,ϵ. The Gromov-Witten invariants can be defined as

Math.text: Psi _ (list@(A, g, m)) * vector@(alpha _ 1, ldots, alpha _ m) = (sum _ I)@((integral _ U _ (list@(I, epsilon)))@((product _ i)@((e ^ *) _ i * alpha _ i))) and Lambda _ I * Theta _ I

para.p: for ∈αi⁢H*(M,R) represented by differential form, where ei is the evaluation map. It is proved that these integrals are independent of the choices of ΘI and the regularization (see [CT]), if they exist. The key issue is the convergence of the integrals near each lower strata. We use the gluing argument. Let =b(u1,u2;∧Σ1Σ2,j1,j2), where (Σ1,j1) and (Σ2,j2) are smooth Riemann surfaces of genus g1 and g2 joining at q and :ui→ΣiM are J-holomorphic with =⁢u1(q)⁢u2(q) We use the holomorphic cylindrical coordinates (si,ti) near q. In terms of the holomorphic cylindrical coordinates we write

Math.text: Sigma _ 1 - set@(q) = Sigma _ 10 * union@(set@(closed-open-interval@(0, infinity) * S ^ 1))
Sigma _ 2 - set@(q) = Sigma _ 20 * union@(set@(open-closed-interval@(- infinity, 0) * S ^ 1))

para.p: Over each tube the linearized operator Du takes the following form

Math.text: D _ u = partial-differential / partial-differential@(s) + J _ 0 * (partial-differential / partial-differential@(t)) + S

para.p: where →|⁢∂+kl⁢∂sk∂tlS|0, exponentially and uniformly in t as →s∞. To recover a Fredholm theory we use weighted function spaces ⁢W1,p,α(⁢u*TM).

For any gluing parameter :=(r)(r,τ) we construct a surface =Σ(r)⁢Σ1#(r)Σ2. Then we glue the map (u1,u2) to get the pregluing maps u(r), a family of approximate J-holomorphic maps. Denote by :Qb→Lp,α×KbW1,p,α a right inverse of ⁢DSb Then ⁢DSb(r) is surjective for r large enough ( for the notation ⁢DS see §4) . Moreover, there is a right inverses Qb(r). By implicit function theorem, there exists a small open set O of ∈0⁢KerDSb(r) and a unique smooth map
such that for any ∈(κ,h)O

Math.text: (bar@(partial-differential)) _ J * (exponential _ u _ r)@(zeta) + kappa _ v = 0

para.p: where

Math.text: open-interval@(kappa _ v, zeta) = open-interval@(kappa, h) + (Q _ b _ r compose f _ r) * open-interval@(kappa, h)

para.p: Put

Math.text: formulae@(E _ 1 assign K * e * r * D * S _ u _ 1, formulae@(E _ 2 assign K * e * r * D * S _ u _ 2, H = T _ q * M))

para.p: Denote

Math.text: K * e * r * D * S _ b assign E _ 1 * (direct-sum _ H)@(E _ 2)

para.p: We can prove that when r large enough there is an isomorphism

Math.text: I _ r colon K * e * r * D * S _ b longrightarrow K * e * r * D * S _ b _ r

para.p: Then we get a gluing map +⁢Ir(κ,ζ)⁢∘Qb(r)f(r)Ir(κ,ζ) from ×Oj1Oj2O into the moduli space, where O is a neighborhood of 0 in ⁢KerDSb, Ojk is a neighborhood of jk, =k1,2. Then ((j1,j2),r,τ) is a local coordinate system in Delingne-Mumford space. We may choose ((j1,j2),r,τ,κ,ζ) as a local coordinate system in the moduli space. A important estimate in this paper is the following

p.text: There exist constants >C0, 0<α<1⁢16e4 such that for any >r⁢4R0

Math.text: (norm@((partial-differential / partial-differential@(r)) * (I _ r * open-interval@(kappa, zeta) + (Q _ b _ r compose f _ r compose I _ r) * open-interval@(kappa, zeta)))) _ (list@(1, 2, alpha, r)) less= C * e ^ (- alpha * ((l * r) / 8)) * (norm@(open-interval@(kappa, zeta))) _ (list@(1, 2, alpha))

p.text: Restricting to the compact set {≤|si|R0}, we have

Math.text: absolute-value@((partial-differential / partial-differential@(r)) * (I _ r * open-interval@(kappa, zeta) + (Q _ b _ r compose f _ r compose I _ r) * open-interval@(kappa, zeta))) less= C * e ^ (- alpha * ((l * r) / 8)) * (norm@(open-interval@(kappa, zeta))) _ (L ^ infinity)

para.p: We use this estimate to show the convergence of the integrals (1). This estimate is also important in proving the virtual smoothness of the moduli space. In this paper we need the following theorem of exponential decay in [MS] and the implicit function theorem (see [MS],[SL]):

p.text: For any 0<c<1, there are two positive constant C1 and ℏ depending only on J, ω and c such that for any J-holomorphic map :u→×[-R,R]S1M with

Math.text: formulae@(absolute-value@(nabla@(u)) * open-interval@(s, t) less= C _ 1 * e ^ (- c * (R - absolute-value@(s))), for-all@(absolute-value@(s)) less= R - 1)
formulae@(absolute-value@(nabla@(u)) * open-interval@(s, t) less= C _ 1 * e ^ (- c * (R - absolute-value@(s))), for-all@(absolute-value@(s)) less= R - 1)

p.text: Let (X,∥⋅∥X) and (Y,∥⋅∥Y) be Banach spaces, ⊂UX be an open set and :F→XU be a continuously differentiable map. Let ∈x0U be such that ::=D⁢dF(x0)⟶XY is surjective and has a bounded linear right inverse :Q⟶YX with ≤∥Q∥C2 for some constant >C20. Choose a positive constant >ℏ10 such that

Math.text: formulae@(norm@(d * F * x - D) less= 1 / (2 * C _ 2), for-all@(x) element-of B _ Planck-constant-over-2-pi _ 1 * x _ 0)
formulae@((norm@(F * x _ 1)) _ Y less Planck-constant-over-2-pi _ 1 / (4 * C _ 2), (norm@(x _ 1 - x _ 0)) _ X less= Planck-constant-over-2-pi _ 1 / 8)

p.text: Then there exists a unique ∈xX such that

Math.text: formulae@(F * x = 0, formulae@(x - x _ 1 element-of I * m * Q, formulae@((norm@(x - x _ 0)) _ X less= Planck-constant-over-2-pi _ 1, (norm@(x - x _ 1)) _ X less= 2 * C _ 2 * (norm@(F * x _ 1)) _ Y)))

p.text: Moreover, write :=x+x0ξ⁢∘Qf(ξ), ∈ξ⁢kerD. If :F⟶UY is of class Cℓ, where ℓ is a positive integer, then f is of class Cℓ.

para.p: We recall some fundamental concepts in symplectic geometry (see [MS]). Let (M,ω) be a symplectic manifold. An almost complex structure :J→⁢TM⁢TM is called ω-tame if

Math.text: v not-equals 0 Longrightarrow omega * open-interval@(v, J * v) > 0

para.p: for every ∈v⁢TM. It is called ω-compatible if it is ω-tame and

Math.text: omega * open-interval@(J * v, J * w) = omega * open-interval@(v, w)

para.p: for every ∈xM and ∈v,w⁢TxM. Every ω-tame almost complex structure J determine a Riemannian metric

Let (M,ω,J) be a closed symplectic manifold of dimension ⁢2n with ω-tame almost complex structure. Let (Σ,j) be a closed Riemann surface. A map :u⟶ΣM is called a (J,j)-holomorphic map if =∘⁢duj⁢∘Jdu. Alternatively

Math.text: (overline@(partial-differential)) _ J * u = (1 / 2) * (d * u + ((J compose d) * u) compose j) = 0.

para.p: We will omit j and call u ”J-holomorphic map” later to simplify notations. Since Σ is closed, ∈[⁢u(Σ)]⁢H2(M,Z)
Denote by B the space of W1,p-maps :u⟶ΣM with a fixed homology class ∈A⁢H2(M,Z) that is

Math.text: B = conditional-set@(u element-of W ^ (list@(1, p)) * open-interval@(Sigma, M), u _ star * delimited-[]@(Sigma) = A)

para.p: where p is an even integer greater than 2. Then B is an infinite dimensional Banach manifold. For any ∈uB the tangent space at u =⁢TuB⁢W1,p(Σ,⁢u⋆TM)

Let E be the infinite dimensional Bananch bundle over B whose fiber at u is Lp(Σ,u⋆TM⊗C∧0,1T⋆Σ), the space of Lp-section of the bundle u⋆TM⊗C∧0,1T⋆Σ. The Cauchy-Riemann operator defines a smooth Fredholm section :¯∂J⟶BE The zero set of this section

Math.text: M = ((overline@(partial-differential)) _ J) ^ (- 1) * 0 subset-of B

para.p: is the moduli space. The energy of a smooth map :u⟶ΣM is defined as the L2-norm of the 1-form ∈⁢du⁢Ω1(Σ,⁢u*TM):

Math.text: E * u assign (1 / 2) * (integral _ Sigma)@(((absolute-value@(d * u)) ^ 2) _ J * differential-d@(v) * o * l _ Sigma)

para.p: Note that the energy density |⁢du|2J depends on the metric on Σ. It is important that the energy of a J-holomorphic map is a topological invariant that depends only on the homology class ⁢u⋆([Σ]):

Math.text: E * u = (integral _ Sigma)@(u ^ * * omega)

para.p: Let =Σ⋃πv(Σv) be a semi-stable curve. Denote by =Q{p1,…,pν} the set of nodal points of Σ. Put Σ∘=Σ-Q. Let u:Σ∘→M be a J-holomorphic map. We choose cylinder coordinates (s,t) near each nodal point pi. Over each tube the linearized operator Du takes the following form

Math.text: D _ u = partial-differential / partial-differential@(s) + J _ 0 * (partial-differential / partial-differential@(t)) + S

para.p: It follows from Theorem 1.2 that →|∇u|0, exponentially and uniformly in t as →s∞. By the elliptic regularity we have, for any >k0

Math.text: (sum _ (i + j = k))@(absolute-value@((partial-differential ^ k)@(S) / ((partial-differential ^ i)@(s) * (partial-differential ^ j)@(t)))) less= C _ k * e ^ (- c * s)

para.p: for some constants >Ck0. Therefore, the operator =Hs+⁢J0d⁢dtS converges to =H∞⁢J0d⁢dt. Obviously, the operator Du is not Fredholm operator because over each nodal end the operator =H∞⁢J0d⁢dt has zero eigenvalue. The kerH⁢i∞ consists of constant vectors in ⁢TpiM. To recover a Fredholm theory we use weighted function spaces. We choose a weight α for each end. Fix a positive function W on Σ which has order equal to e⁢α|s| on each end, where α is a small constant such that 0<α<c and over each end =-H∞α-⁢J0d⁢dtα is invertible. We will write the weight function simply as e⁢α|s| For any section ∈h⁢C∞(Σ;⁢u∗TM) and section ∈η⁢Ω0,1(⁢u∗TM) we define the norms

Math.text: (norm@(h)) _ (list@(1, p, alpha)) = ((integral _ Sigma)@(((absolute-value@(h)) ^ p + (absolute-value@(nabla@(h))) ^ p) * differential-d@(mu))) ^ (1 / p) + ((integral _ Sigma)@(e ^ (2 * alpha * absolute-value@(s)) * ((absolute-value@(h)) ^ 2 + (absolute-value@(nabla@(h))) ^ 2) * differential-d@(mu))) ^ (1 / 2)

(norm@(h)) _ (list@(1, p, alpha)) = ((integral _ Sigma)@(((absolute-value@(h)) ^ p + (absolute-value@(nabla@(h))) ^ p) * differential-d@(mu))) ^ (1 / p) + ((integral _ Sigma)@(e ^ (2 * alpha * absolute-value@(s)) * ((absolute-value@(h)) ^ 2 + (absolute-value@(nabla@(h))) ^ 2) * differential-d@(mu))) ^ (1 / 2)

(norm@(eta)) _ (list@(p, alpha)) = ((integral _ Sigma)@((absolute-value@(eta)) ^ p * differential-d@(mu))) ^ (1 / p) + ((integral _ Sigma)@(e ^ (2 * alpha * absolute-value@(s)) * (absolute-value@(eta)) ^ 2 * differential-d@(mu))) ^ (1 / 2)

(norm@(eta)) _ (list@(p, alpha)) = ((integral _ Sigma)@((absolute-value@(eta)) ^ p * differential-d@(mu))) ^ (1 / p) + ((integral _ Sigma)@(e ^ (2 * alpha * absolute-value@(s)) * (absolute-value@(eta)) ^ 2 * differential-d@(mu))) ^ (1 / 2)

para.p: for >p2, where all norms and covariant derivatives are taken with respect to the metric ⟨⟩ on ⁢u∗TM and the metric on Σ. Set

Denote by ⁢W1,p,α(Σ;⁢u∗TM) and Lp,α(u∗TM⊗∧0,1) the completions of ⁢C(Σ;⁢u∗TM) and C(u∗TM⊗∧0,1) with respect to the norms (14) and (15) respectively. The operator :Du→W1,p,αLp,α is a Fredholm operator so long as α does not lie in the spectrum of the operator H⁢i∞ for all =i1,⋯,ν.

p.text: The index ⁢ind(Du,α) does not change if α is varied in such a way that α avoids the spectrum of H⁢i∞ Conversely, the index will change if α is moved across an eigenvalue. We will choose α slightly larger than zero such that at each end it does not across the first positive eigenvalue.

para.p: For each nodal point =pi,i1,…,ν, let ∈h⁢i0kerH⁢i∞. Put =H∞(H⁢1∞,…,H⁢ν∞), =h0(h10,…,h⁢ν0) We choose a normal coordinate system near each nodal. h0 may be considered as a vector field in the coordinate neighborhood. We fix a cutoff function ϱ:

Math.text: varrho * s = cases@(Array[[1, i * f * absolute-value@(s) >= d], [0, i * f * absolute-value@(s) less= d / 2]])

para.p: where d is a large positive number. Put

Math.text: (hat@(h)) _ 0 = varrho * h _ 0

para.p: Then for d big enough ^h0 is a section in ⁢C∞(Σ;⁢u∗TM) supported in the tube {(s,t)|≥|s|d2,∈tS1}. Denote

Math.text: W ^ (list@(1, p, alpha)) = conditional-set@(h + (hat@(h)) _ 0, formulae@(h element-of W ^ (list@(1, p, alpha)), h _ 0 element-of k * e * r * H _ infinity))

para.p: We define weighted Sobolev norm on W1,p,α by

Math.text: (norm@(open-interval@(h, (hat@(h)) _ 0))) _ (list@(Sigma, 1, p, alpha)) = (norm@(h)) _ (list@(Sigma, 1, p, alpha)) + absolute-value@(h _ 0)

para.p: Let =Σ×RS1 =E×ΣR⁢2n Let :π⟶EΣ be the trivial vector bundle. Consider the Cauchy-Riemannian operator D on E defined by

Math.text: D = partial-differential / partial-differential@(s) + J _ 0 * (partial-differential / partial-differential@(t)) + S

para.p: where =⁢S(s,t)(⁢S⁢ij(s,t))⁢×⁢2n2n is a matrix such that (13) hold. Therefore, the operator =Hs+⁢J0d⁢dtS converges to =H∞⁢J0d⁢dt as →s∞. We choose weight α for each end as above and define the space ⁢W1,p,α(Σ;E) and Lp,α(E⊗∧0,1). By an observation of Donaldson we know that the multiplication by W gives isometries from W1,2,α to W1,2 and L2,α to L2 and

Math.text: formulae@((norm@(f)) _ (list@(2, alpha)) = (norm@(W * f)) _ (L ^ 2), C ^ (- 1) * (norm@(W * f)) _ (W ^ (list@(1, 2))) less= (norm@(f)) _ (list@(1, 2, alpha)) less= C * (norm@(W * f)) _ (W ^ (list@(1, 2))))

para.p: Consider the operator

Math.text: D colon W ^ (list@(1, 2, alpha)) rightarrow L ^ (list@(2, alpha))

para.p: It is equivalent to the map (see [D],P59)

Math.text: D _ W assign D - (partial-differential / partial-differential@(s)) * logarithm@(W) = W * D * W ^ (- 1) colon W ^ (list@(1, 2)) rightarrow L ^ 2

para.p: Let ∈hW1,2,α be the solution of the equation =⁢Dhη where ∈ηL2,α Obviously,

Math.text: D _ W * W * h = W * D * W ^ (- 1) * W * h = W * eta

para.p: Let =ρ⁢Wη,=f⁢Wh Then f satisfies the equation =⁢DWfρ
We consider the operator :-Dα→W1,2L2 We write =-Dα+∂∂sLS, where :=L-⁢J0∂∂tα is a invertible elliptic operator on S1 when 0<α<1.
The space ⁢L2(S1) can be decomposed two infinite spaces H+ and H- (see P33 in [D]), where

Math.text: formulae@(H ^ + = conditional-set@(sum@(a _ n * e ^ (square-root@(- 1) * n * t)), n >= 0), H ^ - = conditional-set@(sum@(a _ n * e ^ (square-root@(- 1) * n * t)), n less 0))

para.p: Since L is an invertible operator, there exists a complete eigen-function space decomposition such that =⁢Lϕλ⁢λϕλ where >|λ|δ for some >δ0. Obviously, ∈λ-Zα By choosing 0<α</12 we have =αmin|λ|
Using the same method of Donaldson in [D] we can prove the following lemma:

Math.tex: \sum_{i+j\leq 1}\left|\frac{\partial^{i+j}S}{\partial^{i}s\partial^{j}t}\mid_{% \{(s_{o},2lr-s_{o})\times S^{1}\}}\right|\leq Ce^{-\mathfrak{c}s_{o}},\;\;\;\;% \;\mbox{ for any }R_{0}\leq s_{o}\leq lr.

p.text: For any 0<α<min{c,12} there exists a constant >C0 such that for any h defined on ×(0,⁢2lr)S1 satisfying =⁢Dh0, we have

Math.text: formulae@(evaluated-at@((delimited-∥∣@(h)) _ (set@(open-interval@(s _ o, 2 * l * r - s _ o) * S ^ 1)), list@(1, p, alpha)) less= C * e ^ (- alpha * s _ o) * (norm@(h)) _ (list@(2, alpha)), R _ 0 + 1 less= s _ o less= l * r)

para.p: We only consider gluing one nodal case, for general cases the gluing are the same. Let =b(u1,u2;∧Σ1Σ2,j1,j2), where (Σ1,j1) and (Σ2,j2) are smooth Riemann surfaces of genus g1 and g2 joining at q and :ui→ΣiM are J-holomorphic with =⁢u1(q)⁢u2(q) Let zi, =i1,2, be the local complex coordinates of Σi with ⁢z1(q)=⁢z2(q)=0. Without loss of generality we fix the complex structures j1, j2. The neighborhood of ∈∧Σ1Σ2¯Mg,m is given by

Math.text: formulae@(z _ 1 * z _ 2 = w assign e ^ (- R - 2 * pi * square-root@(- 1) * tau), w element-of C)

para.p: Put =R⁢2lr, ∈lZ+. We will use (r,τ) as the local coordinates in the neighborhood of ∈∧Σ1Σ2¯Mg,m. Let

Math.text: formulae@(z _ 1 = e ^ (- s _ 1 - 2 * pi * square-root@(- 1) * t _ 1), z _ 2 = e ^ (s _ 2 + 2 * pi * square-root@(- 1) * t _ 2))

para.p: (si,ti) are called the holomorphic cylindrical coordinates near q. In terms of the holomorphic cylindrical coordinates we write

Math.text: Sigma _ 1 - set@(q) = Sigma _ 10 * union@(set@(closed-open-interval@(0, infinity) * S ^ 1))
Sigma _ 2 - set@(q) = Sigma _ 20 * union@(set@(open-closed-interval@(- infinity, 0) * S ^ 1))

para.p: For any (r,τ) we construct a surface =Σ(r)⁢Σ1#(r)Σ2 as follows, where and later we use (r) to denote gluing parameters. We cut off the part of Σi with cylindrical coordinate >|si|⁢3lr2 and glue the remainders along the collars of length ⁢lr of the cylinders with the gluing formulas:

Math.text: t _ 1 = t _ 2 + tau
t _ 1 = t _ 2 + tau

para.p: We glue the map (u1,u2) to get a map u(r) from Σ(r) to M as follows. Set

Math.text: u _ r = cases@(Array[[list@(u _ 1, o * n * Sigma _ 10 * union@(conditional-set@(open-interval@(s _ 1, t _ 1), formulae@(0 less= s _ 1 less= (l * r) / 2, t _ 1 element-of S ^ 1)))), ], [, ], [u _ 1 * q = list@(u _ 2 * q, o * n * conditional-set@(open-interval@(s _ 1, t _ 1), formulae@((3 * l * r) / 4 less= s _ 1 less= (5 * l * r) / 4, t _ 1 element-of S ^ 1))), ], [, ], [list@(u _ 2, o * n * Sigma _ 20 * union@(conditional-set@(open-interval@(s _ 2, t _ 2), formulae@(0 >= s _ 2 >= - (l * r) / 2, t _ 2 element-of S ^ 1)))), ], [, ]])

para.p: To define the map u(r) in the remaining part we fix a smooth cutoff function :β→R[0,1] such that

Math.text: beta * s = cases@(Array[[1, i * f * s >= 1], [0, i * f * s less= 0]])

para.p: and -1β is a smooth function, ≤|⁢β′(s)|2. We assume that r is large enough such that ui maps the tube {(si,ti)|≥|si|⁢lr2,∈tiS1} into a normal coordinate domain of ⁢ui(q). We define

Math.text: u _ r = u _ 1 * q + beta * (3 - (4 * s _ 1) / (l * r)) * (u _ 1 * open-interval@(s _ 1, t _ 1) - u _ 1 * q) + beta * ((4 * s _ 1) / (l * r) - 5) * (u _ 2 * open-interval@(s _ 2, t _ 2) - u _ 2 * q)

para.p: By using the exponential decay of ui one can easily prove that u(r) are a family of approximate J-holomorphic maps, precisely the following lemma holds.

Math.text: (norm@((bar@(partial-differential)) _ J * u _ r)) _ (list@(p, alpha, r)) less= C _ 2 * e ^ (- (c - alpha) * r)

p.text: The constants C2 in the above estimates are independent of r.

para.p: For any η∈C∞(Σ(r);u(r)∗TM⊗∧0,1)), let ηi be its restriction to the part ⁢Σ⁢i0⋃{(si,ti)|<|si|⁢3lr2}, extended by zero to yield a section over Σi. Define

Math.text: (norm@(eta)) _ (list@(p, alpha, r)) = (norm@(eta _ 1)) _ (list@(Sigma _ 1, p, alpha)) + (norm@(eta _ 2)) _ (list@(Sigma _ 2, p, alpha))

para.p: Denote the resulting completed spaces by Lrp,α. We define a norm ∥⋅∥1,p,α,r on ⁢C∞(Σ(r);⁢u(r)∗TM) For any section ∈h⁢C∞(Σ(r);⁢u(r)∗TM), denote

Math.text: h _ 0 = (integral _ (S ^ 1))@(h * open-interval@(l * r, t) * differential-d@(t))
h _ 0 = (integral _ (S ^ 1))@(h * open-interval@(l * r, t) * differential-d@(t))

para.p: We define

The lemma can be generalized to the case of gluing several Riemann surfaces and several nodal points.

It is well-known that if Du is surjective for any b=(u,(Σ,j);y)∈⁢¯MA(M,g,m), then ⁢¯MA(M,g,m) is stratified by smooth orbifolds. When the transversality fails we need to take the stabilization ( we use the terminology ”regularization” in this paper). In [R3] and [LR] the authors outlined a regularization procedure. In [CT] Chen and Tian introduced a class of new objects ”virtual manifolds/orbifolds”, developed the integration theory and discussed systematically and more clearly the regularization procedure for both Fredholm system and orbifold Fredholm system. This is a very useful tool to study moduli problem. In this section we explain simply the method in [CT, CLW] and suggest the readers to see [CT, CLW] for details.
A virtual manifold is a collection of smooth manifolds :=X{XI}∈II indexed by a partially ordered set (=I2{1,2,⋯,n},⊂), together with patching data

Math.text: conditional-set@(open-interval@(Phi _ (list@(I, J)), phi _ (list@(I, J))), formulae@(list@(I, J) element-of I, I subset-of J))

p.text: where :ΦI,J→XJ,IXI,J is a vector bundle with the zero section :ϕI,J→XI,JXJ,I for open sub-manifolds XI,J and XJ,I of XI and XJ respectively, whenever ⊂IJ. The patching datum (ΦI,J,ϕI,J) for ⊂IJ will be simply denoted by
